meaning_mnemonic: The アメリカ part is pretty easy so long as you know katakana. It's the word for "America." You know that <kanji>人</kanji> means "person," so you can figure out that America + Person = <vocabulary>American person</vocabulary> — specifically a <vocabulary>person from the USA</vocabulary>.
フランス is "France." So what is a "France person?" That would be a <vocabulary>French person</vocabulary>.

When you see a katakana word, it's a safe bet that it is a foreign loan word from somewhere else. This one's interesting, because it combines katakana and kanji! The first <vocabulary>marble</vocabulary> came to Japan from Portugal, so the ビー part of the word is short for "vidro," which means "glass" in Portuguese. Anyway, don't get thrown off by that ビー. Maybe just imagine that your favorite marble is black and yellow like a bee.

Since this is a kanji with hiragana attached that ends with an う sound, you know that this word is a verb. What's the ultimate verb version of the kanji 生? That would be <vocabulary>to be born</vocabulary>, the very beginning of <kanji>life</kanji> as we know it!

Normally a single kanji alone like this would mean the same thing as its parent kanji, but in the case of <kanji>生</kanji> it's a little different (but still related). When you think of something that has life, it's <vocabulary>fresh</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>raw</vocabulary>. Think sashimi or sushi, for example. You want that to be as close as possible to life as you can, so you eat it when it's fresh and raw. This word can also be used to describe a <vocabulary>live</vocabulary> event, like a concert or sporting event. 

You'll see this word at the beginning of other words. For example, 生たまご is "raw egg."

When you have <kanji>one</kanji> <kanji>ten thousand</kanji> you just have <vocabulary>ten thousand</vocabulary>. In Japanese, though, you specify how many ten thousands you have, though (which is weird in English, but should make sense if you think about it).
When you have <kanji>two</kanji> <kanji>ten thousand</kanji>s, you have <vocabulary>twenty thousand</vocabulary>.
<kanji>Ten</kanji> <kanji>ten thousand</kanji>s is equal to <vocabulary>one hundred thousand</vocabulary>.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
The <kanji>now</kanji> <kanji>day</kanji> is what day? Oh, it's <vocabulary>today</vocabulary>.
The <kanji>now</kanji> <kanji>month</kanji> is actually <vocabulary>this month</vocabulary>.
You have <kanji>half</kanji> a <kanji>part</kanji>. Half a part is still <vocabulary>half</vocabulary>, right?

This word has the same meaning that you learned with the kanji: <vocabulary>part</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>portion</vocabulary>. By extension, it can also mean <vocabulary>content</vocabulary>, as in "alcohol content" because that's the portion of alcohol in a drink.

This word is used for fractions, too, as in one third or one quarter. Again, you can see how this links to "parts" and "portions", right?

Think back to the old old olden days. Back when decisions were made with swords. A <kanji>big</kanji> <kanji>cut</kanji> is going to be <vocabulary>important</vocabulary>. Just imagine a couple samurai squaring off, then charging, then making one big cut. It's the most important thing they'll do in their lives (if they live!).

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>cut</kanji>, and the verb form of that is <vocabulary>to cut</vocabulary>.

A person who is a friend is just that, a <vocabulary>friend</vocabulary>!

Note that 友人 is a more formal word that’s often used in professional settings.
This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of the <kanji>fat</kanji>? It's the same: <vocabulary>fat</vocabulary>.

This word is a single kanji with hiragana attached, though there is no specific clue as to what type of word it is. That means you can usually guess it's a noun, adverb or na-adjective (in this case it's a noun / adverb). The meaning of this word is pretty much the same as the kanji, though, making it fairly easy. The kanji meaning for <kanji>少</kanji> is <kanji>few</kanji>, and the meaning of the vocab form is <vocabulary>a little</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>a few</vocabulary>.
This word has a single kanji with hiragana attached, ending in a い. This means you know it's an adjective. What is the adjective form of <kanji>few</kanji>? It's also <vocabulary>few</vocabulary>.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>pull</kanji> and the verb version vocab means <vocabulary>to pull</vocabulary>.

This word can be transitive or intransitive. You use 引く in a transitive way to say you pull something, for example. But it can also mean <vocabulary>to withdraw</vocabulary> when you talk about things that pull back, like water that recedes, pain that subsides, soldiers that withdraw, or even your body recoiling when something puts you off.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

A <kanji>door</kanji>'s <kanji>mouth</kanji> is the <vocabulary>doorway</vocabulary>! 

戸口 is mostly used for doorways that lead outside. It has an old-fashioned feel to it and is becoming less common these days, especially in spoken Japanese.

You might notice that this word resembles 出口 (exit) and 入り口 (entrance). Like in those words, the character 口 just represents an opening here.

The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

You learned 方 means <vocabulary>direction</vocabulary>, but it can also mean <vocabulary>way</vocabulary>, as in この方がいい (this <vocabulary>way</vocabulary> is better) or やり方 (the <vocabulary>way</vocabulary> of doing something). 

Interestingly, 方 can also be used to refer to people politely, like こちらの方 (this person). This is because, in traditional Japanese, people—especially noble ones—were often referred to indirectly, as if indicating their presence from a direction.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>stop</kanji>, so the verb vocab version of that is <vocabulary>to stop something</vocabulary>. Alternatively, it can also mean <vocabulary>to stop doing something</vocabulary>.

You're in the <kanji>middle</kanji> of something when someone yells "<kanji>stop</kanji>!" They hit you with a <vocabulary>cancellation</vocabulary> order and demand the immediate <vocabulary>discontinuation</vocabulary> of all your activities. Welp, it looks like you've been canceled — better go find something else to do.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. This is the polite and humble form of <vocabulary>father</vocabulary>. You use this when you're talking about your own <vocabulary>dad</vocabulary> to other people in formal settings, especially if you aren't very close to them.

This word begins with an honorific (お), making whatever comes after it more elevated. Then there's 父, which you know means <kanji>father</kanji>. Lastly, we have the honorific name-ender <ja>さん</ja>. So this is a nice way to say <vocabulary>father</vocabulary>. 

You'll want to use this when you're addressing or calling out to your own <vocabulary>dad</vocabulary>, or when you're talking about him or someone else's dad in a casual setting.
The kanji and the word are the same. This word is a bit broader than <vocabulary>cow</vocabulary> though, and can also be used to be <vocabulary>bull</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>ox</vocabulary>.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>old</kanji>? It's also <vocabulary>old</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>ancient</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>out-of-date</vocabulary>.

This word is used for things like clothes, food and friendships, but not for people! So a 古い友人 (old friend) is someone you've been friends with for a long time, not an elderly friend.

The combination of kanji doesn't make perfect sense, but it's alright. Take something that's <kanji>middle</kanji> <kanji>old</kanji> and you have something that's <vocabulary>used</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>secondhand</vocabulary>. It's not 100% old yet... it's still in the middle, meaning you can give it to someone else to use, like your younger siblings.
As long as you know the two kanji that make up this word, you should be able to figure out the meaning of this word as well.
When you combine these two kanji, you should be able to see how it forms the word <vocabulary>two machines</vocabulary>.
As long as you know both of the individual kanji meanings, you should be able to put together this one to get <vocabulary>five machines</vocabulary>.
If you know the two kanji separately, you should be able to put them together to form the meaning of this kanji.

The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

Note that 外 doesn't always simply indicate the physical position of something. It can also be used figuratively to refer to what's outside of one's inner circle or home.

An "outside person" is a <vocabulary>foreigner</vocabulary>. This word is fairly common, though it's not super polite, either. It's okay most of the time, but it can be used derogatorily depending on the situation. The more polite version is 外国人 (outside country person) but you won't learn that until you learn the kanji for 国.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

When the <kanji>city</kanji> <kanji>stand</kanji>s something up, that thing becomes <vocabulary>municipal</vocabulary>. You know, like a <vocabulary>city-run</vocabulary> library or a city-run gym or something. The city is what keeps that place standing.

The name of the city (シアトル／しあとる) with a <kanji>市</kanji> attached to it means it is "the city of ____." You can do this with any city (try it out on your hometown!). So this word means <vocabulary>Seattle</vocabulary>, or more specifically <vocabulary>City of Seattle</vocabulary>.
This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>wide</kanji>? It's also <vocabulary>wide</vocabulary>.

The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they both mean mother. 母 is a formal and humble way to say "my mother" when talking to others. By using the plain form and omitting respectful language toward your own mom, you actually sound more humble, which makes a polite impression on the person you're speaking to. You wouldn't, however, use it when talking to your mom or when talking about someone else's mom — it would come off as too blunt for that!

This word begins with an honorific (お), which generally adds a nuance of respect or politeness to what comes after it. Then there's 母, which you know means <kanji>mother</kanji>. Lastly, we have the honorific name-ender さん. So this is a nice way to say <vocabulary>mother</vocabulary>. You use it when talking about the <vocabulary>mom</vocabulary>s of friends or casual acquaintances, when talking about your own mom in a casual social setting, or when talking to your own mom.

In more formal settings, you'll want to use 母 (pronounced はは) to talk about your own mom and the super respectful お母さま to talk about someone else's mom.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>task</kanji> or <kanji>use</kanji>. You can think of this verb as a more formal way to say <vocabulary>to use</vocabulary>, and that is <vocabulary>to utilize</vocabulary>.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
The kanji for <kanji>person</kanji> and <kanji>life</kanji> combined makes you think about human life. What is your <vocabulary>human life</vocabulary> like?
イギリス means "Great Britain" or "United Kingdom." So what is a "Great Britain person?" You guessed it — a <vocabulary>British person</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>Brit</vocabulary>.

The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

When this kanji is a word on its own, it's actually very often written in hiragana. Still, the kanji version of the word is worth knowing, too!

This counter is used with some kind of <kanji>machine</kanji> or device, usually a fairly large one (so nothing itty bitty). Cars are a good example of this. But it can also be used for things like computers, which were once the size of rooms, but are now nice and small. Thanks technology!

When you see this on a number, for example ７人 or ３人, you're using it to count people. Just remember, both 一人 and 二人 have alternative readings. From 3 and up it's just the number plus にん, like this. ５人 is ごにん, １０人 is じゅうにん, etc. This is the <vocabulary>counter for people</vocabulary>, which makes this word the <vocabulary>number of people</vocabulary>.

A <kanji>little</kanji> <kanji>woman</kanji> is a <vocabulary>girl</vocabulary>. 

少女 is a relatively formal word that's often used in writing to describe a <vocabulary>young girl</vocabulary>, usually between childhood and adolescence (or between the ages of about five and eighteen).

When a vocab word is a single kanji without okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) it usually has the same meaning as the kanji it's spawned from. If you know the kanji meaning you'll also know the vocab meaning. It's <vocabulary>ten thousand</vocabulary>!

This is a strange one. It's こんにちは, which you've probably heard before, but it's spelled using the kanji <kanji>now</kanji> and <kanji>day</kanji>. So when you say "now day!" you're really saying <vocabulary>hello</vocabulary>!

Warning! Don't mix this up with きょうは! While they may look the same, they don't mean the same thing. We will only ever ask you for こんにちは, so please try to remember that!

We usually don't use kanji for this, so don't use it when you're writing. But you'll probably run into it in the wild so it's good to know!
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

Remember how you learned that 大人 means "adult?" Well this is the adjective version of that. The I-adjective (see how it ends in い?). What adjective do adults want to be able to use for their own kids? They want to say they are <vocabulary>obedient</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>quiet</vocabulary> kids!

A <kanji>door</kanji> is a <vocabulary>door</vocabulary> — the kanji and the word are exactly the same.

戸 can refer to any kind of door, but it's more commonly used for <vocabulary>sliding door</vocabulary>s, since those are the traditional style of doors in Japan. For Western-style or high-tech doors, people tend to just say ドア.

A <kanji>woman</kanji> <kanji>person</kanji> is a <vocabulary>woman</vocabulary>.

The の particle here means the first noun is modifying the second one, so you can probably see why 女の人 (a woman person) really just means woman! It's more polite than saying 女 by itself, so that's all you have to remember.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. 

The kanji itself means <kanji>wide</kanji>, and the verb version is what happens when you try to make something wider. How do you make something wider? That's right, you have <vocabulary>to spread something</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to unfold something</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to open something up</vocabulary>. All of those actions will make a thing wider!

This is a transitive verb. That means it takes a direct object. You spread something. Like a newspaper, or a cloth on a table.

You know that 山 means mountain. Add the hiragana びこ to the end and this gives you <vocabulary>echo</vocabulary>. That's because bee children (bee 子) love echos, especially <vocabulary>mountain echo</vocabulary>s! Imagine baby bees buzzing as loudly as they can and hearing their voices echoing back at them through the mountains.

As the kanji suggests, 山びこ is generally used to describe the echo you get if you shout in the mountains. To describe other types of echo, you can use the katakana word エコー.

By the way, there is actually a kanji for the second part of this word, but it's so rare that it's usually written in kana!

First we have a katakana word, so it's safe to assume that it's a loan word. Like many loan words, it comes from English. Say it out loud and what do you have? That's right, "table". Then comes the particle の, which joins two nouns together. Finally we have 上, which you learned means "up" or "above". Put all of these pieces together and we have a phrase meaning <vocabulary>on the table</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>tabletop</vocabulary>!

This starts with another katakana word, so you can assume that it's a loan word. This one also comes from English. Can you figure out what it means? That's right, "bed". Then comes the particle の, which joins two nouns together. Finally, we have 下, which you learned means "down" or "below". Put these elements together and you get <vocabulary>below the bed</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>under the bed</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>beneath the bed</vocabulary>. What's under your bed?
What do we call the <kanji>sun</kanji>'s <kanji>exit</kanji> from the horizon? That'll be the <vocabulary>sunrise</vocabulary>. Imagine the sun exiting the horizon and climbing up into the sky.

You just learned the vocab 生, meaning fresh. Combined with the katakana word for beer makes this draft beer or unpasteurized beer.

Note that while in a lot of countries, "draft beer" refers only to beer that's drawn from a keg, 生ビール can also refer to unpasteurized canned or bottled beer, giving it a shorter shelf-life, but also keeping it fresh.

Remember how 入り口 means "entrance" and 出口 means "exit"? This vocab is just the 口 part with a direction added to it. This also makes it both an entrance or exit. So when you have the kanji for <kanji>north</kanji>, it makes this both a <vocabulary>north exit</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>north entrance</vocabulary>. This is a great word to know if you need to know which side of a train station you need to leave on to go somewhere or meet someone!

What makes it <kanji>bright</kanji> around here? It's <vocabulary>light</vocabulary>!

Note: 明かり is mostly used for light coming from a specific source, like a lamp or light bulb. You'll learn a more general word for light in a couple levels.
